Alright, after 6 hours of playing this game and hitting level 20, I think I can review this now, because I'm not about to waste any more time playing this game.

I'll start with the Pros.
Pros:
-Good looking game, variety of enemies, and I liked the coloring.
-A decently big tree filled with Talents and skills, but only sub classes per each class, (4 classes, 2 subclasses each)
-I thought the music was pretty nice.

Cons:
-BARELY any bag space, if you want more bag space, guess what? $$$$$$$
-Adds nothing unique to the genre, very bland.
-Barely any players (Probably because you have to pay to get in, there will probably be a lot more in the next week)
-Very, and I repeat, VERY generic mmo. The quests consist of gather that, kill this, talk to this guy, give this guy this, etc etc and they have you running around huge amounts of land which is very time consuming.
-Forced PVP in some areas, I got killed without knowing twice by some random player while doing a quest.
-Obviously a Pay to win game, even the cosmetics give you +5% hp or +5% stamina, and those are just items ON TOP of your actual equipment. I have also not received a regular mount 20 levels into the game, so paying is your only option to get a mount as far as I can see.
-Again, very generic mmo, this game would have been good 8 years ago.
conclusion: this game isn't worth your time, there's way better mmorpgs out there.

reviewText:
Don't let the idea that you can purchase premium currency with in game gold fool you, this game is pay 2 win.

If you're high level (50+), you can earn enough gold to pay for a premium membership (or royal blessing, as it's called), but there's much more to be had with premium currency. More backspack in your tiny backpack? Pay up. Per item type (equipment, loot, potions, quest items). Would you like to revive instantly? Pay up. Fast travel for no gold? Pay up. Pet collars? Pay up. In fact, you're constantly nagged with functionality that requires you to either get a premium membership or pay a one time fee in premium currency. Constantly.

If you don't have a premium membership, you receive a lot less gold, experience and loot. Your resurrecting sickness lasts seven times longer, and much much more.

The game itself is alright. There are tons of different spells, and different classes really do feel like different classes. Some quests are unique and interesting, but most are fetch, deliver or kill quests. The PVP wasn't well thought through, and can be tedious at times. Most areas look similar, and enemies are not very unique in the way they act.

The chat is horrendous and unintuitive. This leads to very little chatter over the airways and a sort of isolated feeling, as if you're not really in an mmorpg.

Overall, the relentless pushing to get you to pay up spoils most of the fun, especially since your basic account is so limited it's hard not to feel pressured into spending money. I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
TOP QUESTION: Is this game P2W (Pay to Win)
ANSWER: The short answer is NO, however, let me go in depth with this...

When you start this game you get 3 days free premium this gives you:

+50% EXPERIENCE AND DROP RATE

PORTAL SKILL (This allows you to save 5 places and teleport to it at any time including Maidens (Rogues/Assassin/Thief get a skill called Secret Lair which allows you to save only one spot but its free!)).

FREE TELEPORTATION BETWEEN MAIDENS (Even without premium it doesn't cost that much)

+10 QUESTS IN QUEST LOG (I have never needed 30 quest slots even at low levels where I had 18 quests at one time, even with dailies (I will go more in depth into the dailies later on).

PETS AND MOUNTS

Pets are utility centric as in they do nothing but pick up drops for you they do require you buy SIlver/Gold Magnet Collars from Cash Shop, they have a durability called Charge, 1 Charge = 1 drop picked up (Pets are not worth the trouble having other than aesthetics you can easily just pick up the drops yourself with spacebar).

Mounts again are utility centric they offer increased movespeed as well as various stat boost such as attack or health, they require Mount Feed from Cash Shop, Crusader/Dark Knight can get Mounts that do not require food for 300G from Ricker in Varlone City he is in the centre square off to the top right and from Ronda in Iris out of the South Gate of Varlone, these Mounts only give movespeed bonus (Mounts are semi useful for all classes as the buffs from them last for 1 hour even if you dismount, only the classes I mentioned can do mounted combat). You can also use Grass Chewing Gum which gives you 20% Runspeed for 15 minutes, you can get it from a daily quest or dropped from monsters (its rare to get a drop), you can also buy it from the Market fairly cheap.

A Mount and a Pet can be bought from an NPC (Head of the Merchant Guild) to the south of city square in Varlone City.

Reales can be bought from Market for 10-14k gold per Reale, 10x Mount Feed is 29 Reales and last for 1 hour each (290-406k for 10 hours of extra buffs, which you totally dont need if you are just PVMing although it would be useful), Silver Collar 2000 Charge is the same 29 Reales. You can get 100x Mount Feed for 269 Reales and Gold Collar 9000 Charge for 99 Reales. This is on the EU Maragorne Server.

BAGS AND WAREHOUSE

You have 14 slots for each type of item they are split into Equipment, Expendables, Loot and Crafting Items. You can store excess/rare items in your Warehouse which has 27 slots available accessible at any Maiden. The 2 Bags that get full fairly quickly are Expendables and Loot but once you learn what you should keep and what should be sold to NPC or put on the Market you won't have too many bag problems.

EQUIPMENT, ITEM IMPROVEMENT AND SEALING

ALL Equipment in the game can either be bought from NPCs, Crafted, Dropped from Monsters, Found in Dungeons (Marked by a Cross Shaped Grave Stone with Blue particle effects, these are mostly personal so you will not be able to sell them on the Market) or bought from Players via the Market.

Item improvement is done through Alchemists you will know the NPC is an Alchemist because they will have an Alchemical Cauldron next to them which is used to craft recipes. Philosopher Stone Chips are used to upgrade C Class Equipments only, Philosopher Stone Shards are used to upgrade B and A Class Equipments. Ashkalot Cubes can be used to upgrade any item while reducing its cost and protecting it from breaking (there is a daily to get these cubes), Cash Shop items can help in your upgrading but if you start using those before level 40 you are just wasting your money.

Sealing is EXPENSIVE, this allows your equipment to gain extra stats quality of seal is as follows from worst to best Green/Blue/Purple/Orange. Emeralds are used to seal C Class Equipments, Sapphires for B Class Equipments and Morions for A Class Equipments. Crystal Vessels can be obtained through a daily quest, this item can be used to grant you Blood Crystal which can be used to place a new seal on an already sealed item (The current seal will be DELETED and a NEW seal put on). Emerald, Sapphire, Morion and Crystal Vessels can be purchased from Master of Enchantment outside of Academy of Magic Varlone City bottom right of map. Cash Shop items only help to alter the seals already on the equipment or to allow the lowest quality of Blue to be added.

DAILIES AND X2 EXPERIENCE

There will be many dailies but the two worth mentioning are Caustic Acid (This nets you 3 Ashkolot Cubes for 50 Caustic Acid) and Green Slime (This nets you 2 Crystal Vessels for 50 Green Slimes), you can take these quests soon after you hit level 20 from the Message Board in Varlone City centre to the bottom right. You can also get a free Emerald along with 2 Potions from Protecting the Vegetable Garden from Pests taken from Connor Barr in Elgore. You can bring up available quests by hitting the M or Q key and clicking the Available Quests tab top right (You will need to bring up the map and click this tab and quest to see where to go for it each time you lose your way).

You will gain resting bonus experience if you are not on your character for more than 8 hours to a max of 20 hours this works on all quests and monsters you gain experience from will be doubled till it is depleted.

BELLA THE RARITY BUYER AND SELLA THE COLLECTOR

Cards are rare drops from monsters which can be given to Bella for Insignia's of Distinction or sold on the Market. Various items can be bought from Sella for Insignia's of Distinction including PREMIUM TIME as well as a few things that can be bought in Cash Shop which includes Decorations that give +5% Health. They are both located in centre court of Varlone City to the northwest. You can also gain Insignia's of Distinction by PVPing in PVM/PVP areas Rewards are given monthly and you must be in the top 20 PVPers.

CRAFTING

Most loots are used for crafting, C Class Equipments are 100%, B Class 80% and A Class 60%. Flax is important in crafting you find this randomly by digging up plants. Ores are also found scattered around areas and as you progress through the game you will find the higher quality ores, digging ores also gets you Anthricite. Elum is obtained through Equipment that you put in the Splitter, the higher level the Equipment the more Elum you will get, Red Elum comes from Weapons, Blue Elum comes from Clothing (Armor, Headgear etc), Green Elum comes from Accessories (Rings, Amulets etc). So keep those Equipment drops! if you plan on crafting (Crafting gets you personal gear with slots, the same as Dungeons). WARNING keep all Gem drops if you do plan on crafting as they drop rarely and are used in recipes at high levels. Some Crafting Recipes can be bought from NPCs inside of PVM/PVP areas, they require you gather Elenium nodes which will give you Alchemical Runes with which to buy the Recipes. Recipes also drop from monsters. You can find all the machines necessary for crafting/splitting at the east side of Varlone City, SPECIAL NOTE the Elenium Converter requires Alchemical Runes to change 1 material to another.

PVP FIGHTING ARENA

Pushing A on your keyboard brings up a Menu with Battleground, Arena and Store (in the Center, Blue button), You can join Arena 5 times a day to earn Blood Tokens which in turn can be used to buy from the Arena Store to improve your prowess vs other players, there is also a Mount and Pet as well as various potions.

To conclude the game is beautiful the music is great and I enjoy playing it for free.

I hope you found this Review(Guide) informative and insightful.

Royal Quest is incredibly enjoyable, but be prepared to loosen your purse strings.

Pro's:
- Satisfies the desire for an old-school grind MMORPG.
- Many skills and combos, great for PVE and PVP.
- Guild wars.
- Castle sieges.
- Challenging raid content.

Con's:
- Very Expensive Cash Shop (A few friends have spent >$5,000 on upgrades/equips on a geared max level character).
- P2W is the foundation of being good end game.
- Only two populated guilds.
- Player population is very low and dwindling.
- The DEV team does not engage or communicate with the player population.
- Patches are geared towards the cash shop, never game balance, updates, or fresh content.
- Extremely overpowered / underpowered classes.

To recapitulate this game was fun while it lasted, but is now far past its prime and not worth the monetary investment.

reviewText:
This game is really fun. I don't understand how people are voting it down because you have to click to move. Like, have you played Diablo/Torchlight? Get over it. Anyway, back to the game:

It's an MMO, so be prepared for a lot of fetch quests. Besides this, it does some pretty unique things.

First of which would be the leveling system. It's typical in the sense that every level you get stat points and sometimes a talent point, but the stat system is really cool. basically, every 10 points put into a specific stat, you get an extra bonus to it, and your 'rank' in that stat increases. So if I put 10 points into stamina, which is the rangers base stat, I'll get +15 to my damage output, on top of the points I put into it. Very unique and I enjoy ranking up stats.

The talent point system is also fairly unique, as they're all passives. There are multiple paths to travel down, which each give your class a unique playstyle. I'm not sure if there's a way to reset these, but I'm sure there is.

This game is NOT pay to win. You can obtain the premium currency by using gold, the in-game currency. Actually, gold is pretty easy to obtain as well, and so are most of the items in the game. It could be a bit of a grind, but that's how most MMOs work anyway, so it's not a big deal.

I really have been enjoying my time with this game. It's fun, it's a good time waster, and it feels like there's been a lot of love and time put into it, in order to make it good. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun MMO to play with.

You start with 2 toolbars for skills, but the top one is bound to Alt+# instead of the F-keys, which feels odd to me.

The health meter is too small, not attracting enough attention to it, and as it's placed in the upper left cornor, it's easy to overlook it in a fight because the action is always closer to the toolbars.

The initial graphics settings are OK, but even with everything cranked as high as it'll go there's very little change aside from adding shadows and foliage.

I can't comment on whether there's P2W or not becasue, honestly, I haven't seen it. But as I ahven't explored a lot of this game it could be there and I just haven't seen it.

Honestly, as this is a F2P game, it's up to you whether to try it or not. It's not bad but it's not great either, so I'm 50/50 on this game.

Pros: Free to Play. Brought some successful elements from Ragnarok Online, which I enjoyed. Graphics Updated from RO, but.. Good flexibility for hot keys. Many premium items can be obtained in-game, but..

Cons: The list of cons is huge.

1. Graphics are updated, but .. mediocre by today's photorealistic qualities.

2. It is definitely a free to play, but PAY TO WIN, model. In comparing the relative speed at which pay users achieve end game characters and equipment, I would estimate that the pay players are at least 5 times faster to achieve their goals over the average free player. This is evident by players who have started around the same time as me (free player), but have already been miles ahead of me in a matter of days, and I'm not one of the average free players, myself. Likewise, many who play much less, are already left behind in the dust.

3. Grinding end game levels will definitely put you on your knees, and that's even with a premium membership. Yea, lots of level grinding. I've heard of a L55 premium sniper complain about it. And when you see L22~26 players grinding on L50+ mobs..and the max level is L60..you know, something is wrong here. When you die, above L20, you are exposed to a 10 minute status ailment called weakness, that halves your attack and defence. The only way to get rid of it immediately is to pay the npcs gold, gold that escalates every level higher than L20 you are. So each time you respawn, you've got to do something else to wait out the weakness time..otherwise cough up (or go premium, which reduces that time to 1 min).

4. Earning in-game currency is really horrendous. It's subtle, but with a closer look, you'll see that the loot that you bring in from the monsters, especially true for the higher levels, are not only few, but they hardly add up to buy a single health potion of equivalent level. The rest of the loot can be vended, but only with a time-restricted stall that you need to purchase for more coin..So what does this mean? It simply means, you'll have to farm loot with minimum potions/foods most of the time unless you can successfully fetch a good price for your vended goods. Other times, you'll have to rely solely on the gold earned through quests, and there aren't that many well paying quests after you've completed your main ones. On top of all that, if you've got weakness, you've got to wait it out before you can even start farming for loot.

5. PvP everywhere, if you're a friendly, social player like myself, you'll hate the PvP, but that's fine of course, if it's confined to themselves and we PvEer are left to our own entertainment. Sadly, that is not entirely true. The guild system has a lot of perks, like discounted npc prices, better drop rates, better running speed, more defence, more attack and a social community. However, past rank 10, and the guild is prone to other guilds declaring war on it. Some high level players have decided to band together in a certain guild (unnamed, but it could be anyone) in an effort to extort protection tax from smaller guilds so that they will not be PKed outside of towns..it's kind of like how the triads extorts everyday citizens.
I guess this is a reflection of the situations real Russians face..but still..
THIS IS A BIG DOWNER.

6. A massive rip off from the once popular Ragnarok Online. Not that, that in itself is a bad thing, since they had done a lot of concepts right. And most games these days are copied from one another. Big Deal.

I could say more, but I have to go.
Stay away like the PLAGUE!!

lack of inventory, lack of buyable mounts outside of cash shop, forced purchase of teleport to gain access to town with out suiciding, etc.

This game is just not fun. I've played MANY mmo's with a cash shop that pushes itself upon you often yet those games, cashshop aside, were still fun regardless. Mabinogi is a prime example of this, great gameplay, deep plot with now 15 or so different main stories to experience back to back all adding new mechanics and types of combat styles. There's just so much GOOD with Mabinogi that the cash shop is just a small bother by comparison of the fun you can have with the game with out the cash shop.

This game on the other hand, is just flat out NOT FUN. I was expecting a Diablo-esk style mmo with the topdown view faster point/click style combat and such but no, a single click auto attacks, the spells and skills take FOREVER to charge and cast, quests are boring and generic fetch quests like most mmo's seem to be doing these days, tho top it off the visuals aren't even good enough to validate it's existance. I'm not saying visuals are EVERYTHING but if the game itself isn't fun at least make it look decent enough that you'd want to stare at it for a while. But no it doesn't even do that properly.

reviewText:
First Impressions of the game: The color choice and aesthetic is great, many colors, nice feel to the game, though often very bland in areas that are heavily paved (like the main city). The aesthetic shines the most in field areas with a bit of blending between one zone and the next.

The second thing I notice, is that the Camera is locked in this psuedo-isometric position, which allows full rotation, but limiting tilt. you can look almost straight down at your character if you wish, or at a slight angle, but you are incapable of looking parallel to the ground, let alone being able to see any trace of sky. (Probably to lessen the system-demand for rendering, and the need for a skybox)

The third thing I notice is the obvious Premium service. The game practically screams P2W. I honestly wouldn't mind if there were some benefits to paying players, but what ruined it was the constant self-advertising. The fact that you'd have a Premium / VIP tab right above the hotbar that remains there forever, alongside tabs that would remind you of unspent skill points or stat points. It's also a nuisance to see that little blue 'Premium' tab at the center of your screen as you try to pay attention to skill cool downs and potion counts.

The game spends quite a bit of effort reminding you that you 'could' be enjoying the game better if you paid for it.

Next on the list is the combat, which is a bit dull. It's your standard auto-attack, use skills when ready, repeat on the next bad guy. What's interesting though, are the passive skills (Talents) that somewhat modify the properties of previously obtained Active skills, though quite a bit of advancement is required.

After your first class advancement, you gain this Rift-style 3-option talent tree, in which you can specialize, or become a jack of all trades. Specializing yields you a powerful (or less-than-powerful) active skill at the end of one of the three trees for your class. But frankly, the three-tree system is nothing close to the way Rift handles it, and feels like a dumbed down 'my-first-RPG' experience.

The game itself lacks depth from the beginning, and the overall pacing is slow, the quests are un-engaging, and are your standard 'go kill me some wolves for their pelts' ordeal. Occasionally you will get some quests that mess with the props in the environment, or sends you on an errand run across NPCs, concluding in an encounter with an instance (or psuedo-instance)

Here's another drawback that really bothered me. The fact that what I had assumed what were instanced dungeons, are actually open to other players. Caves, Underground Libraries, Sewers, were all loaded with players with the same quest, therefor your target monster or drop would also be hunted by several other people, making your 25 Slime kill quest last longer than it really should. My only experience with a true instance were the randomly spawning 'entrances' that whisked you away to an extremely linear and un-engaging mini-dungeon, or one of the Boss Dungeons that I fought with a party of four.

Though with that drawback, there is also a certain benefit: The Community. The early-game community is pretty large, everywhere you go you are guarenteed a sighting of another player probably doing the same thing as you, hunting Monsters. Not just one, but many players, all hunting monsters, all having a bit of fun. That's nice. Having lots of players around is nice, which makes this experience slightly more enjoyable. Sort of like you and your friends going to a really really bad theme park, somehow with your friends you were able to squeeze some fun out of it, despite the actual place itself being an uninteresting experience.

There are also a few somewhat innovative features: Like castles that could be fought over for guild dominance (though I haven't experienced this feature myself) as well as competitive 'deathmatch dungeons' were you can grind for loot and exclusives materials only if you can survive the onslought of players doing the same thing. (essentially an open PVP dungeon that only allows you to keep your loot if you can escape). Even a raid boss would wonder into town to face the innumerable number of players turning in their quests, leading to a 15-20 player assault on the big ol' boss guy.

---

In the end the game is colorful and full of life, but also in turn, is uninteresting, even annoying, when alone amongst crowds of other people, all competing for a limited supply of Monsters. The game has it's moments when partied up, and certain aspects are enjoyable, with a few speckles of innovation. But overall, the game feels like an RPG experience lacking in depth, but not lacking in it's P2W ego. It's a game worth trying out to see if it fits you, but also is a game worth completely ignoring if you're a hardcore MMO'er looking for deep an immersive RPG experience.

Not Recommended, but try it anyway.

reviewText:
I'll try to keep it short and sweet. I played till level 52. Didn't use premium/blessing until level 30.

Pros:
-Sweet time waster with lots of fun for early levels.
-Making decent gear for class C items (1-30 ish) is easy and fun. Most materials are obtainable from daily quests with easy to farm items.
- Exploring the maps with mobs that can kill you in 1 to 2 hits is fun. Basically it is fun to be noob in this game.

Cons:
- P2W.

Gold cost for gear improvements and seals increases at almost triple or more  from each class. Just look at the NPC price of Emeralds compared to Sapphires compared to Morions. Without mentioning the required cashshop items for item improvements as the success rate for higher class item is much lower if using non-cash cubes

Premium/Blessing is a must to play at later levels even when 60. Gold/time costs of weakness debuff after death is very high, and players can die a lot especially when playing in areas with range mobs or during guild wars. Maiden tele costs adds up without Blessing. (7K here, 8K there and all your gold farmed is gone) Another thing is the tax on non-preimun account for players setting up markets is ridiculous (15% vs 5%). Either spend time spamming to sell instead of enjoying the game or suck it up losing 10% extra.

TL/DR:

Reccomended for those who like grinding games with an objective to reach level cap and for causal/serious pvping in lower levels.  Not reccomended for those who wants level cap PvP because the costs is too prohibitive for most. (too grindy or too P2W)

reviewText:
I really don't like the yes or no rating on steam, but I guess I'll settle on no.

The top-down camera and point and click work fine, but it can be touchy in situations where ranged characters need to kite and dodge large creatures. And picking up loot Ragnarok style gets old fast; loot should either be automatic, walkover, or corpse collection, not 5 items sprawled on the ground each needing its own click.

The inventory complaints I've seen in reviews are somewhat unfounded. Yes, there are only about 14 bag slots, but there are 5 different bags for different types of items, so in essence, there are a lot more.

Quests are the standard, but they require treking back and forth repeatedly, with random spawn points, which is extremely tiring and annoying.

The game is decent; in depth skill trees, unique play-style classes, decent graphics. Enjoyable for some, but anyone seeking a game to grab them and make them want more should look somewhere else.

levels 1-20 = having fun, playing casually, (taking the bait)
levels 20-40 = more challenge, figuring out your class and game goals (getting hooked)
levels 40-50 = sinking more time & money into the game you didn't expect (you can't turn back now)
levels 50-59 = hoping that the max level 60 will change the game for you (being disillusioned)
level 60 = looking to get in a top guild, throw all your time & money at the game (your fate)

Now when you get to level 60 typically the last thing you do before finishing your character is finding all the normal and Elite/Boss monster cards you need.

reviewText: I'm making this review to show people wanting to play the experience that someone who spend over 5-10 hours before making a  review has had. Most of the negative reviews are telling you things that are true about this game. Yes bag slots are low and you have to pay to get more, there are cash shop mounts, and there are items in the cash shop that give you SMALL bonuses especially campared to the cards in the game, which are found when killing mobs or a few unique kinds from the cash shop. (which aren't very useful endgame) What these people failed to mention is that this is a FREE game. Free games always have to make someway of making profit and profit = cash shop. But by far it is not P2W, you can buy your own premium currency fairly cheap with your own gold that you earned ingame. And the cash shop items aren't even that expensive if you do decide to pay.  For example, a crystal key, which opens a chest that can give you a majority of things only costs 99 Royal Reales, which is less than 5$. As someone who opened 2 of these chests I got a mount that would have cost me 20$ and a 7-day premium scroll. Also on the PvP dungeon side of things, yes you are killed, yes you are camped when you enter one. But what reviewers have failed to tell you is that it WARNS you before entering saying YOU CAN GET KILLED. This is a PvPvE game if you don't like PvP quit or go somewhere there isn't PvP. As of now there are things we still don't know about the game, but I  have had a lot of fun playing it and it does have some interesting content that I have not seen in many MMOs, such as war and the card system. War is when 1 guild declares war on another, no matter where you are (discluding towns) the enemy guild can kill you. This is very fun especially if you enjoy PvP. And cards are very rare drops that each mob has that can give you special bonuses, some are good and some are bad. You can equip these cards in equipment with card slots. So please, if you are thinking of playing this game, take advice from someone who has played way longer than many of the negative reviewers. Just give it a try yourself, who knows it might be your new favorite game.

First Impressions.

-Cash Shop,

Additional Notes.

reviewText:
This game is beta, so I found the intro and stuff really bad.  Probably they'll clean that up when not beta?  I don't know, but the first 10 levels seem pretty pointless.  After that the game starts to get more interesting.  So overall this game is pretty fun.  I prefer full 3d, the view on this takes getting used to.  You do tend to get player killed in some areas without knowing why and with no warning, even from people in your own guild... so that's kind of weird, just kind of walking along then out of the blue -- dead.  But does't seem to do much to you other then stick you back at a maiden.   But the free play on this is pretty fun so far, still not as compelling as other MMORPGs I've played, but it's got a lot of depth, so you keep discovering stuff.  It's a pretty light weight client too so you can easily play it on any machine.

I _hate_ the dependence on mouse for everything.  I'm used to using keyboard for moving around at least somewhat, your mouse hand gets pretty tired in this game.  Not sure why they don't have keyboard support.

I would give it thumbs down if  I actually paid for it.  But it's a free game.  It's stable, and more than somewhat entertaining.  What more can you ask for for free?    I've been playing for abput 80 hours now and it's already getting really boring though.

I've seen absolutely no compelling reason to spend real money on this game.  If it required money I would never buy or play it.   It's a piece of garbage compared to any real MMORPG such as Everquest, WOW, or LOTRO.  And LOTRO is F2P and is much, much, much, better.  On LOTRO you end up wanting to spend money to add new zones... which actually makes sense -- pay money, get good content that you actually desire.  Versus pay money and get a disposable weapon enhancement... blah ... so you can PK someone in a game where PK has no meaning since the PVP combat system is kludged and unbalanced to death - or that's my interpretation of it anyway.

PROS:
1. you can play it on your laptop, so can play from anywhere, it's got low quality graphics so doesn't require much of a machine.  Seems to work fine on any machine.
2. stable game, rarely crashes, rarely have network / connection issues
3. it is a graphical MMORPG and F2P, so if you want to do some mudding there you go

5. For someone like me who used to play text-based muds a lot, I'm still impressed with any mud with graphics!
6.  Randomized tiered reward system, so kind of like an easter egg hunt type model.  Every once and a while you find really cool stuff from even the weakest creatures.

CONS:
1. If I actually spent money on this game, I'd have to be insane.  I regularly will be happy to spend money on games, money is not the issue.  But I absolutely refuse to play $10 real for an in game suit of armor.  Or a dollar for transport, or anything stupid like that.  When the designers are so out of touch of the value of a dollar, it just pisses me off and turns me off to spending any money on the game.  If you are stupid enough to put real money into this game, go find a non-free MMORPG and put your money there instead, you'll have more fun.  The value of this game is only in the fact that it is free.
2. Low-end annoying graphics, not impressive, boring, and difficult to look at, it's some sort of fake weird angle 3D that really bothers my eyes and makes the side of my brain hurt for some reason.

4. all the toons look like teenagers.  makes me never want to take screenshots... i take screenshots and they always suck.  That says something there.
5. the story line absolutely sucks.  I've tried to read the quests and they make no sense... There is no art to the game basically... just a bunch of grunt work hunter gatherer quests.
6. All the quests seem exactly the same.  There seems to be a pretty small set of canned quests types that everything is derived from at all levels.
7.  No spirit.  This game has no spirit and no artistic elements.  There is a feeling like I've already been there and done that with every element of this game.   And nothing new or special about it -- probably the same thing.  So it's kind of the same old grinder mud type game in a new setting with new quests if you have some time to kill and can ignore the fact that your toon looks like a spoiled teenager.

reviewText: I'm making this review to show people wanting to play the experience that someone who spend over 5-10 hours before making a  review has had. Most of the negative reviews are telling you things that are true about this game. Yes bag slots are low and you have to pay to get more, there are cash shop mounts, and there are items in the cash shop that give you SMALL bonuses especially campared to the cards in the game, which are found when killing mobs or a few unique kinds from the cash shop. (which aren't very useful endgame) What these people failed to mention is that this is a FREE game. Free games always have to make someway of making profit and profit = cash shop. But by far it is not P2W, you can buy your own premium currency fairly cheap with your own gold that you earned ingame. And the cash shop items aren't even that expensive if you do decide to pay.  For example, a crystal key, which opens a chest that can give you a majority of things only costs 99 Royal Reales, which is less than 5$. As someone who opened 2 of these chests I got a mount that would have cost me 20$ and a 7-day premium scroll. Also on the PvP dungeon side of things, yes you are killed, yes you are camped when you enter one. But what reviewers have failed to tell you is that it WARNS you before entering saying YOU CAN GET KILLED. This is a PvPvE game if you don't like PvP quit or go somewhere there isn't PvP. As of now there are things we still don't know about the game, but I  have had a lot of fun playing it and it does have some interesting content that I have not seen in many MMOs, such as war and the card system. War is when 1 guild declares war on another, no matter where you are (discluding towns) the enemy guild can kill you. This is very fun especially if you enjoy PvP. And cards are very rare drops that each mob has that can give you special bonuses, some are good and some are bad. You can equip these cards in equipment with card slots. So please, if you are thinking of playing this game, take advice from someone who has played way longer than many of the negative reviewers. Just give it a try yourself, who knows it might be your new favorite game.

reviewText:
This is a pretty unique little gem of a free MMORPG with a somewhat deceptive item shop.
Before I start - the item shop IS NOT mandatory.

Everything in this game is purchaseable with ingame currency, including the premium currency itself. It is expensive, but you can buy it with in game gold.

All in all, this reminds me of some old school point and click action bar MMORPGs similar to Lineage and specifically a game called Ferentus, but a lot more polished and with a very well presented UI and ideas.

Summary:
-8 classes to choose from (4 in the beginning)
-a variety of ways to min/max your attributes
-crafting is very important and the only way to get best items (so far)
-item shop is very very optional
-lots of PVE content, but mostly traditional MMORPG grindy stuff
-encourages grind with rewards...lots and lots of rewards
-a million ways to customize your character to your taste stats wise
-okayish graphics and good sounds effects

All in all, this is by far one of the better free MMORPGs I played in a long while and has a very fair item shop that is very non intrusive.
I definitely recommend this to the fans of the genre and especially those old school players that miss some of the older MMORPGs

reviewText:
I like this game a lot. Step 1 to enjoying it, like any MMO, is finding people to enjoy it with, Once you have that down it is gravy.

This is a PVP game but PVP is entirely optional. Don't want to PVP? Don't go into the elenium caves, don't queue for a BG or duel.

A very few might say this  game is pay 2 win but in my experience it isn't. There are many things you can buy from the cash shop but free players can buy them too. The cash currency 'reales' is tradable and often bought and sold. The cash shop items are also commonly bought and sold. The most popular being 'blessing scrolls'. There re 3/7/14/30 day varieties and they are basically a 'subscriber' type buff for XP and a few other things. No weapons or armor are cash shop items. Of the items in the cash shop that gives bonuses, equivilent items not in the cash shop are superior. I could buy a +5% HP decoration or I could work for one that can't be bought for cash and has a card slot. It is like this for all items even mounts.

The game gets regular updates. In a recent update called Patch of the Crusader" the class I play as was completely reworked. Before the patch there was a very specific objectively best path to work through. This was because many skills were so weak as to never be used and others being so powerful as to being crutches. This was reworked as to allow multiple ways for the class to be used without one being objectively best. In addition some classes got buffs/fixes/nerfs. As is the far easiest classes to level are the two mages and the sniper.

Some people complain about the grind but I have found the grind to not be very bad compared to other MMOs I have played. On the range of "No grind" to "Extreame years long grind" I'd have to put it in the couple months catagory. If you take a mage you can get to level 40 in 3 days and 50 in a week now that enough time has elapsed for people to determine the optimal leveling areas.

reviewText:
It's a pretty good RPG brought to us by the makers of King's Road.

It's a homage to the MMO's of the late 90's, much like the first Ragnarok Online, in a way.

You get to choose from 4 starter classes, and each will branch out into even stronger and
diverse classes which'll make you want to play more -- discovering what each class has to offer.

The visuals are pretty interesting for where the company started. Pretty simple, colors are great,
monster designs are kinda generic (but meh), however the character designs are pretty good.
Music is also fantastic. I can just grind my way listening to the bgm since its so relaxing or so
tense when it needs to be.

Gameplay wise, its a good balance between questing and grinding. Quests scale depending on your
character level so you'll have no problem with it althroughout the first few hours of gameplay.
But since it's this kind of MMO, expect lots of grinding and questing. Theres a fair amount of pvp for all
those people who want a slice of the action. Classes are pretty much balanced.

This game deserves an 8/10 at least! Try it out, it's free :P

reviewText:
I don't know what everyone's problem is that is giving negative reviews. Yes it's pay-to-win and is much like other games, but nowdays, there's just so many mmorpgs, it's hard to find anything unique anymore. Just each games has their own style and variations. And as far as pay-to-win goes, that's what you will get when you play a FREE TO PLAY game... The damn makers of this game have to make money SOME HOW to keep the games going...

Let me get one thing straight about all the negative reviews.... All these things things the negative reviews are complaining about, is just pretty much what you will find in any typical free to play mmorpg.

Now here's my personal opinions on the game so far:

Pros:
The graphics are beautiful for this type of game, way more beautiful than I expected.
The things that you can do to upgrade your gear is a nice feature.
So far from the low level maps, I've found these randomly spawned gravestone things that you can click and go into a mini-dungeon (I assume). I've found these quite fun to do because you can get some decent loot from these. I hope there's more in the game!
The characters and customization all look quite nice. The faces look just a little weird on some of the options, but other than that, I really like it. There's a decent amount of options for you're character's looks, more than even some mmorpgs I've played. I'm a sucker for character customization, so I really hope they add more features to this.
I haven't gotten into crafting (if there is), but what I'm seeing looks like it should be interesting as well.
The classes, skills, and stat points when you leveling, all this I really like. There's a unique (to me anyhow) feature for spending your stat points each time you level.
The amount of options you are given in the settings (graphics, sound, chat settings etc...) is very nice as well. Games that give you a lot of settings and customization is always nice.

Cons-ish:
I do hate the click to move, but from all the mmorpgs/games I've played, I'm use to it by now.
Bag space is annoying, but I just put things in storage I don't keep any time soon, and sell everytime I go into town. So I never really run into many problems with it.
There are pvp zones, I'm not quite sure how it all works, but I look forward to exploring this. From what I've heard though and from what it seems, it doesn't tell you when you are in a pvp zone. Hopefully this stuff will be changed up some.
There is a 10min death penalty. After you die, you're stats are decreased for 10mins, but this can be removed for 500g (which is REALLY easy to get) from the respawn points. So it's not a big deal.

TLDR? The game has it's ups and downs. To best figure out if YOU like the game, I'd honestly suggest trying it out. Like I was saying earlier though, these negative reviews are kind of BS. Their complaints are stuff you will deal with in almost all free to play games.

Every game is going to have at least 1 thing you don't like, after playing games almost my whole like, and 12 years of it being mmorpgs, I've learned you just work around it and deal with it if you like the game enough. No game is perfect :P

I played this game for months on end until I got bored with it.  It has a Diablo-esque feel to it, but there is no real variation to the endgame equipment, the leveling is very grindy, especially after level 40.

I would not recommend that you fall into the trap of the pay to win system.

I really feel that the community I had come in contact with while I was playing is what kept me on board for so long.  After playing the game extensively, I can say this game has little to offer in terms of fresh ideas or new and interesting Action RPG/♥♥♥♥♥♥meplay.

There are other games that have much more to offer, but I had a great run for the time I played.
